Changed macro and macro-contract min-version dep to 2.1.0.beta1 / Updated rubocop configs / Add rubocop to default rake tasks / Updated Readme for to describe contract macro's better

changed macro and macro-contract min-version dep to 2.1.0.beta1
add contributing rules for core members.
Fixing deps and requiring trailblazer-macro-contract in trailblazer
no idea what caused this error before.
In Wrap(), make the mapping simpler. You can now return either true/false, a signal, or the circuit-interface return.
give a name to the Validate activity.

Merge pull request #205 from codetriage-readme-bot/codetriage-badge

Add CodeTriage badge to trailblazer/trailblazer

Add CodeTriage badge to trailblazer/trailblazer

Adds a badge showing the number of people helping this repo on CodeTriage.

[![Open Source Helpers](https://www.codetriage.com/trailblazer/trailblazer/badges/users.svg)](https://www.codetriage.com/trailblazer/trailblazer)

## What is CodeTriage?

CodeTriage is an Open Source app that is designed to make contributing to Open Source projects easier. It works by sending subscribers a few open issues in their inbox. If subscribers get busy, there is an algorithm that backs off issue load so they do not get overwhelmed

[Read more about the CodeTriage project](https://www.codetriage.com/what).

## Why am I getting this PR?

Your project was picked by the human, @schneems. They selected it from the projects submitted to https://www.codetriage.com and hand edited the PR. How did your project get added to [CodeTriage](https://www.codetriage.com/what)? Roughly 5 months ago, [artemasmith](https://github.com/artemasmith) added this project to CodeTriage in order to start contributing. Since then, 5 people have subscribed to help this repo.

## What does adding a badge accomplish?

Adding a badge invites people to help contribute to your project. It also lets developers know that others are invested in the longterm success and maintainability of the project.

You can see an example of a CodeTriage badge on these popular OSS READMEs:

- [![](https://www.codetriage.com/rails/rails/badges/users.svg)](https://www.codetriage.com/rails/rails) https://github.com/rails/rails
- [![](https://www.codetriage.com/crystal-lang/crystal/badges/users.svg)](https://www.codetriage.com/crystal-lang/crystal) https://github.com/crystal-lang/crystal

## Have a question or comment?

While I am a bot, this PR was manually reviewed and monitored by a human - @schneems. My job is writing commit messages and handling PR logistics.

If you have any questions, you can reply back to this PR and they will be answered by @schneems. If you do not want a badge right now, no worries, close the PR, you will not hear from me again.

Thanks for making your project Open Source! Any feedback is greatly appreciated.

Merge pull request #189 from swamp09/ci_aginst_ruby_2.4.1

CI against Ruby 2.4.1
use new activity API where we have :outputs.

Merge pull request #202 from f-mer/fix-tests

Fix tests

replace `decompose` with `to_h`

`decompose` has been removed in version 0.4.1 of trailbazer-activity.
in Validate, use an operation to build the railway.
fix almost all Nested by using the :extension API in Nested.
massively simplify Wrap by using the :argumenter API.
Wrap doesn't need to merge circuit_options.

cool! the Nested() macro now uses the TaskWrap when a dynamic decider is passed into it.
this fixes a bug where that very decider would be called after the :input filter, which
was wrong of course.

simplify Nested::Dynamic by not overriding task_wrap.call_task but by changing :task
and later setting the respective return signal.

start fixing a bug where the Nested callable gets called after the :input filter, which is of course wrong.
[ci skip]
releasing v2.1.0.beta1, after 11 months of work. :fireworks:
better fast track with Nested test.

make all TRB runtime keys symbols, e.g. :params or :model.
use trailblazer/deprecation/context for deprecations.
test tracing with Validate and its nested op.
test Nested with tracing and introspection.
better test docs, and more tests to make sure :input works.

i decided it's better to not even allow Context#merge because it
defeats the idea of hiding information via :input and overcomplicates
the scoping.

in Validate, the representer now gets written to options.
we have to use DI here at some point.
make Contract::DSL load ClassDependencies and warn about deprecation.

Wrap is working.
You can also emit signals other than false!!!

simplify Nested.
we only need to check if "something" is Interface.

nice, we can now use Activity::Railway in Validate and it works™.
this is literally the reason of all the work the past ... 3 months.

start making Nested and Contract work.
one problem is that we don't have a configurable Activity.build(Railway)
Policy uses new macro API which makes Guard and Policy work.
load inject.rb, we need it everywhere.

add another benchmark to show that objects are faster than scopes.
[ci skip]
use Wrap::Input and Wrap::Output from circuit's Wrap.

add some benchmarks.
it shows that the decompose argument feature is a bit faster than doing it manually later in the method.
lots of shit to make variable_mapping work for now.
in Rescue and Wrap, pass circuit_options.
remove Callback as no one was using it and it was a poor idea.
in Nested, use Activity#outputs instead of guessing. This is great! :excited:
use the new macro API for macros.
use the new fast_track: true option.

add variable_mapping to host Input and Output.
This is a generic {Activity} concept and could possibly sit in the activity gem.
consistent interface for In and Output.

Introduce Output with a {filter} (the user's logic to say what variables they want from the nested) and
a {strategy} that currently simply merges the filtered output into options.
more work on Nested and variable mapping.
start working on variables input/output mapping. the last big thing before the first release of 2.1!
don't assume any start states in Nested.
Wrapped now allows to emit false, which is wired to End.failure automatically.

who needs manual wiring when you have Nested?
I love this so much!!! :sparkles:
Wrap doesn't receive any other options anymore.
move method out since that's how it works in 2.0.
add Activity::Task because we only need it here.
Nested now only knows about the {Activity} interface.

move tests to test/nested_test.rb because they're unit tests.
Nested currently only calls the nested operation, and provides wiring.
The input and output should be done via the task_wrap.
test if Nested::NonActivity emits the correct signal for true/false.

better tests for Nested.
introduce Nested::NonActivity that automatically wires success/failure via task_outputs.
let's rewrite Nested to share everything by default, because that should've been the behavior in the first place.

Nested now returns the direction from the actual nested operation.
[ci skip]
start to refactor Nested to use Circuit::Nested.
use Nested.operation_class in Wrap for consistency.

make it a better place by introducing Hash::Immutable.
all this will be cleaned up shortly. however, this prevents people from
doing mistakes and simplifies our workflows.

allow to use any method with the Model macro, e.g.
  ```ruby
  step Model( Comment, :[])
  ```
will now invoke `Comment[ params[:id] ]`, which makes using Sequel
a breeze.
basic Nested working, by actually simplifying it a lot.
disgustingly make the first Nested test working (-l 37).
delete Procedural tests since this module has been removed.
Rescue back working with the new 0.0.8 Option API.

nope, decided to keep the API consistent for the sake of simplicity.
since the 1-arg version of guard steps was never documented, this was a bug.

introduce Operation::DeprectedOptions so we can support steps with one arg, only, eg.

  -> (options) { .. }
make as many stakeholder work on the low-level Task API.

remove old Procedural and friends.
no one needs it.

Merge pull request #184 from 110y/feature/fix_link_in_readme

Fix corrupted link in readme
Fix what we broke in 2.0.5, where `Wrap` would always use the current operation subclass and not the empty `Trailblazer::Operation`. Thanks to @mensfeld.

In Wrap, use `self` instead of a hard class reference.
This allows using Wrap in the compat gem. Thanks @rash-pro for spotting.
when using Nested(X), the automatic :name is now `"Nested(X)"` instead of the cryptic proc string.
Allow overriding the condition in Nested on what's a dynamic object.

remove Rescue module.
the less modules the better, right, @mensfeld? 😜
test if params are passed through in Nested.

Allow specifying what goes out of a nested operation into the outer result.

```ruby
Nested( ..., output: ->(options, mutable_data:, **) { this: "yes" } )
```

Add `Nested(..., input: )` to dynamically decide the input to the nested operation.

fixes #166.

introduce Element and Element::Dynamic as they're both used in a lot of places
and might become a default pattern in TRB/pipetree.

what they do is wrap a declarative option (e.g. a user's step proc, or an options
hash from a DSL method). the Dynamic element simply wraps the option in a Option::KW.

cleanup Nested.
i like the func/OO version better.

introduce functional objects in Nested.
it adds more code but is a hundred times better understandable, faster, and
has stronger interfaces.
Nested( ..., input: -> ) now allows to provide the input for the nested op.

Fix a bug where `Nested( ->{} )` wouldn't `_call` the nested operation and
did too much work on re-nested the already nested params. Thanks to @eliranf for spotting this.

fixes https://github.com/trailblazer/trailblazer-operation/issues/9.
`Guard` now allows kw args for its option.

remove `uber` dependency as we use our own `Option::KW` now.
in `Contract::Build( builder: )` you now also have access to the `name:` keyword. note that you need to double-splat in builders.

    ```ruby
    Contract::Build( builder: ->(options, constant:, **) )
    ```
  same for :method and Callable.

`Guard` now allows a :method.
Policy now passes `(input, option)s` to the condition, which allows to use instance methods, too.
change to Pipetree::Step as this is a generic concept.
be more strict about Validate() kws.

fix a bug in Extract. remove :path parameter in Extract.
test Extract in isolation.

implement Rescue().
implement Wrap(). we now simply use an anonymous TRB operation class for the nested pipe.

TODO: allow pipe.except("operation.new") or something like that.

introduce Guard() and Pundit().
this commit nicely shows the beauty of the new "import" mechanics.

implement Model().

Model now doesn't include anything into the operation class anymore. Use your own Builder or step
if you want to override behavior, which is super simple anyway.

implement Callback().
running a callback group is now completely decoupled from the operation. we still
pass the operation instance to Group::call which means the old API is identical.

TODO: the callback's "result" still has to be implemented in options["result.callback.#{name}"]

start refactoring macros so they always return a strut and their #add options.
introduce Railway::Step to have injectable options without having to write to the operation class.
start testing inheritance. i mean, document it.

test Nested with method and Callable.
// @mensfeld 😬
use Option for Nested( -> ) to allow procs, etc.

Remove Builder, it was the wrong choice and didn't work.
Instead, allow Nested( -> ) with a dynamic nested operation computation.
You can then run the concrete operation via Nested().

Merge pull request #152 from simonini/master

Readme fix example for operation - contract with trailblazer 2.0

Merge pull request #1 from simonini/readme-fix-2.0

Update example of validations for trailblazer 2.0
Update example of validations for trailblazer 2.0
don't write to operation in Contract::Build.
don't write to operation, but options in Validate.
remove Params macro as it is horrible.

It's now Contract::Persist( name: "params" ) instead of ( name: "contract.params" ).
thanks to @cdennl for spotting this inconsistency.

change to
contract.default.params
contract.default.validate names.
simplify inheritance: we actually don't have any concept of "inheriting" anymore, the new call will simply override the old steps.
this reduces our code dramatically while making the user's code only a little bit repetitive. since we want to abandon inheritance
anyway, this is the right direction.

make inheriting more explicit, again.
tomorrow, i will let _insert simply replace existing steps and we won't need override.

use DSL.macro! in all step macros for consistency.
ModuleName.singleton_class will simply make sure the created method
is a "class" method.

Merge pull request #150 from marceloboeira/patch-1

Fix link to trailblazer-operation in the README
Fix link to trailblazer-operation in the README
document that Validate doesn't complain visibly about missing :key.
rm Operation::Controller, we don't need it anymore with trb-rails and trb-endpoint.
playing with the API For Wrap.
every step macro is a function now. :sparkles:
Persist, Contract::* are all macros now.
fix a bug where a nested Rescue appends to the wrong pipe.
use the macro! method to define macro functions for the operation.

execute nested blocks in subpipe context so we don't need the argument.
since this is DSL for creating pipes and executed at compile-time,
you don't really need access to the op class.
add Rescue to catch exceptions of subpipes.
show how to do a rescue "step".
implement first version of Wrap to wrap sub pipes.
extract DSL.insert so we can use that decoration logic for nested pipes.

load all independent features of TRB in trailblazer.rb. according to matz,
this is the new "autoloading". 😂
remove reform monkeypatch, this is in 2.2.3.
add more cool examples for Representer.
nice, now we don't need the format: option in Validate anymore.
simplify Validate's deserialization by using Representable#parse (new in 3.0.2).

allow Validate to use representer.
i might move this to a separate macro one day.
in a world with two tracks, no one needs raise.
in Model, :create is :new now to avoid confusion.

rename user.current to current_user as the namespace doesn't make sense,
and will not work with kw args.
many doc tests for Pundit and Guard.
fix ugly bug in Nested where we would write to the class.

remove Process.
use new high-level step API.
Nested now stops when the nested op was a failure.
no need to go via the operation when we have the skills.
test the result object for Validate.
rename Contract[] to Contract::Build[] for consistency.
the contract's result is now properly written to result.contract.name.
extract procedural legacy code for contract.
extract old procedural #validate into separate file.
use class methods in Contract, too as it's a thousand times more readable.

extract Validate to validate.rb.
don't include any methods anymore for contract.
allow to use your own builder for creating contract. this might soon be extended but does the trick for now.
allow an unlimited number of contracts.
remove Trailblazer::Builder, this is now provided by the Uber gem.
super-simplify builder with the new Uber::Builder API.
show how to use a dry schema *before* the operation is even instantiated.

introduce second "Pipe" object for import! to abstract the details of the pipetree away from modules,
and to allow user options for |.

remove operation.result as a last step. it overcomplicates pipe appending, and is now
back in ::call. this is ok since no one ever will want to override this, and if, they
can by overriding Operation::call.
all modules except for Resolver now use the import! interface.

introduce Stepable (not an english word) to minimize code needed for modules like Contract, Builder, etc,
that can be imported via | into the pipetree.

more tests for persist.
this is where we can add transactions, rescue and whatnot.

make Contract simple again.
introduce key: for Validate to pick the nested key automatically and divert to left otherwise.
everything has to be explicit now.
start implementing ::[] import! for Model, Guard, Contract.
simplify the import mechanism: we don't need modules, we can do it declaratively.

start working out my "pipedream" interface that will minimize "surprises", allow specifying pipetrees
on the operation level by still using the old code.
endpoint code moved over to trailblazer-endpoint.
Model now also sets a result object.
Policy and Guard now return a Result object.
set the contract's validation result under self["result.contract[.name]"].

fix Endpoint test.
Operation::Module shadows Module.
more prototyping, i love the step names already.
set model.result.failure? when find_by didn't work.
allow model action :find_by which won't raise an exception but change to left track since it is &'ed now.

fix policy and guard.
the flag is no "success?" as in the main validation.
add some cool test to pipetree_test! 😍
in Guard, always pass the entire skill hash into the proc.
i need at least 4 days to rewrite this messy test suite.
don't use valid? to find out the result of the validation.

make representers work, again.
i will solve the deserializing better soon.

DSL::Build now allows instances, too, not only classes.
contract with dry-validation works!!!!!! 💥
start integrating Dry::Validation::Schema as an alternative contract into #validate.
move Endpoint to Controller as we now have REAL endpoints!
add ::present, which will stop the pipeline before #call (if you want it there).

add our company name :)
remove the audition paragraph as we don't have to audit anything.

introduce Contract::Explicit for the semi-magic old behavior that allows you to create a contract manually.
introduce Contract::Step to create the contract at a given step [my preferred variant].
the contract now saves its result in ["valid"] not :valid.
extract raise.rb since we might remove it.
Representer now asks for self["model"] and not self#model anymore, much better.
add test where we override Model#model!.

remove any #model readers anywhere. the canonical way is self["model"] and stresses the fact that this is a pipeline.
removed the decoupled ModelBuilder for the sake of including the few methods into the class instead and make them overridable.
introduce Model::Builder module if you only want to override #model!.

make Policy easier to extend.
use "valid" now as key.

the Policy evaluator now only passes the skills hash to #call, no params anymore.
it's the respective permission's job to provide the correct interface, e.g. look a Guard.

add a better interface for policies.
add Guard.
remove Model::Assign and go straight to the skill hash.
at least the test suite runs, again.

fix representer.
i still have to fix the model issue.
merging parts of MORE-PLEASE-MERGE-contract_test because i'm nice.

remove lots of code that we know can achieve by simply rearranging the pipetree. best feeling ever! <3
Builder works.
Model, Policy, Resolver, Builder all work beautifully with pipetree.
we don't need to test External anymore - it's an automatic feature resulting from the pipetree.
test "external" model. this is simply just a changed pipeline now. it's fucking awesome! <3
more tests with model for policy.
simple but effective test with pipetree and Model.
new Policy module does work with Pipetree.

don't include Model, but only Model::DSL when using pipetree.
instead of letting the op instance compute the skills hash, why not do it right away in Op::call?
introduce Trailblazer::Operation::Pipetree and i love it already.

make the entire call stack for Op::call a pipeline.
policy now works.

start prototyping the pipetree support.
for example, the external resolver now works identical to the instance level.

show how easy it is with pipetree to define the order of initialize steps.
it could also be used for the #call part, but not sure ATM if it makes sense, as i kind of like the #process method.

this also massively simplifies the Resolver semantics, as we can see in the next commit.

change to LGPLv3.
this will assure that companies monetizing their versions of Trailblazer either have to open-source their code as well,
or buy a commercial license (to be written, yet).
now that Op::Skill is included per default in Op, we don't need it everywhere.
move the DSL code to Trailblazer::DSL.
make Build better so we don't have to repeat the DSL code.

more tests for the ::contract method.
use .default for every skill.

with Model, always include Setup, too.
all tests running.

allow ::contract to be called several times.
SHOULD THIS ONLY HAPPEN FOR BLOCKS, THOUGH?

almost all External works.
this will be replaced with pipetree.
fix autoloading. this will be removed.
infering the representer from contract now works.

make DSL-callbacks work.
Callback now uses Competence::Builder.
you can now have any number of contracts, with names.

don't use @model anymore but self["model"] - this makes it injectable, e.g. for Resolver.
still have to work out how that works in combination with Setup.
move as much code as possible on instance layer.
use heritage and competences for Model.
allow contract do..end without initializing the constant.
deprecate Op::contract_class in favor of the new competence interface. this also allows injection now without us having to do anything!

in Setup, add :model to result object.
make model_test run.
it's [:operation].contract now, maybe we alias contract in the result object, but i wouldn't know why?
introduce Present as an optional module.
introduce Operation::Run for the old 1.1 behavior (deprecated!).
for simplicity, make Builder a class.
to support namespacing one day, let's use strings for (our) dependency names.
remove operation as it comes from trailblazer-operation now.
Contract uses the new #[] interface for dependencies.
use the way better "new" operation API.
remove Builder since this resides in `trailblazer-operation` now.
in #validate, don't raise any exception anymore. this is very test-specific behavior.

Merge pull request #127 from amoludage/master

Typo fix

Merge pull request #122 from nhocki/patch-1

Fix URL in CHANGES.md

Fix URL in CHANGES.md

Need to add `http://` so GitHub doesn't think it's a linking to a local file.
version bump to 1.2.0 as it's a tiny API change.
add test for Composition contract with injected dependencies.

* Changed `Operation#validate`: the signature now is `validate(params, model=self.model, options={}, contract_class)`.
* Changed `Operation#contract`: the signature now is `contract(model=self.model, options={}, contract_class)`.

Both changes simplify injecting additional dependencies into the contract, or making use of `Composition` contracts.

added deprecation code.
third #contract argument is now options. WIP.

make Op#contract! return the contract instance, only. this makes it in line with #model!, #params!, etc.
the memoizing method is now #contract, which can now be called such as

```ruby
contract(song: model, artist: song.artist)
```

and thus allows compositions and additional options, too.
add a test to show how to use a representer for parsing, only.
Rename `Operation::Representer::ClassMethods` to `Operation::Representer::DSL` and allow to use `DSL` and `Rendering` without `Deserialization` so you can use two different representers.
Add an explicit test against the private `attr_writer` behaviour
Revert existing tests to their @ivar form.
Allow Operation#@model to be set via private setter method

simplify Policy::Guard.
you can now pass a block or a Callable object used as a guard.

Lous has been renamed to Hanami

http://hanamirb.org/blog/2016/01/22/lotus-is-now-hanami.html
document that TRB does all frameworks.

clean up how params is handled in Controller helpers. this fixes the problems with prepopulate! receiving the wrong parameters.
fixes #87.

Add `Controller#params!` that works exactly like `Operation#params!` and allows returning an arbitrary params object in the controller.
Thanks to @davidpelaez for inspiration. fixes #98.
start ControllerTest that tests Operation::Controller#present and friends without having to use Rails.
try to fix build with new bundler.

Deprecate `Dispatch` in favor of `Callback`. In operations, please include `Operation::Callback`. Also, introduced `Operation#callback!` which aliases to `#dispatch!`. Goal is having to think less, and now all naming is in line.
callback methods have to be in block for inline groups. for external callback objects, methods have to be in callback object.

don't deprecate positional args in Controller#run and friends anymore.
there was a bug that prevented :params to be properly passed through. (@acaron, didn't you report that a while ago?)
The only way to let Trailblazer pass a document to the operation is via `is_document: true`. There is _no guessing_ anymore based on whether or not `Representer` is mixed into the operation or not.
make sure Policy#setup! passes the right, explicit params.
add Operation#params! that works exactly like #model!. you can return a differing params hash here if you want to change the params structure while avoiding changing the original params.
run CI for reform 2.0 and 2.1 (currently reform/master).
trailblazer actually works with reform 2.0 and 2.1.
test overriding Representer#to_json works and allows options.
API change: in Representer, the default represented object is now `model` and not `contract` anymore. why would i wanna render JSON of my contract?
instead of using inheritable_attr for callbacks in an operation, use Heritage.
this is trailblazer 1.1.0.beta1 now and requires the newest gems. [ci skip]

Merge pull request #96 from ashtonthomas/fix_readme_link

update link to views

Merge pull request #93 from timoschilling/patch-4

fix readme callback

Merge pull request #92 from MGerrior/patch-1

Fix broken links in README.md
don't return Else anymore from Controller#run, but the operation instance.

remove double private

10 lines up is already a `private`
ok, maybe remove the puts next time before releasing.
In `Controller#form`, the options argument is now passed into `form.prepopulate!(options)`. This allows to use arbitrary options and the `options[:params]` for prepopulation.

Treat all requests as `params` requests unless the operation has a representer mixed in. If you don't want that, you can override using `is_document: false`. This appears to be the smoothest solution for all.
* In `Controller`, `#form`, `#present`, `#run` and `#respond` now all have the same API: `run(constant, options)`. If you want to pass a custom params hash, use `run Comment::Create, params: {..}`.
`Controller#form` now returns the form object and not the operation.
fix Controller and make :js a non-document request, too. fixes #82.
add :js to the list of is_document=false types. no test here, yet.

Merge pull request #80 from timoschilling/patch-2

autoloading for NotAuthorizedError
automatically use the latest ruby versions on travis
better, shorter README with many links to the new website.
move all rails stuff to trailblazer-rails.
remove rails tests, they are in trailblazer-rails now.
no need to run rails tests here.
we don't need rails here anymore.
load builder after Op is defined.
move old reform 1.2/ActiveModel::V code to trb-rails.
remove Operation#present as it should not build the contract and hence became redundant.
remove Operation::compose! in favour of better readability.
test that prepopulate! is really called.
simplify #form tests now that it doesn't much anymore.
no controller dependency in Endpoint anymore.

Controller#form is identical to #present, but it calls @form.prepopulate!
Controller#collection is identical to #present but sets @collection = model.
simplify Endpoint so it doesn't need to fiddle with controller.
you can now properly extend an inherited callback group.
callback now has identical semantics, e.g. `callback :after_save, AfterSave`.
Operation::contract now acts as reader and writer.
starting to rewrite rails tests with rack-test to avoid AC::TestCase.

add test for namespace: option for #respond. thanks to the brillant ActionController::TestCase i can't test this.
if anyone is up to convert all controller tests to rack-test, please gitter me.

API change: Controller#respond now accepts: respond(operation_class, options, params). this is because respond is mostly used in API context where params doesn't need to be altered but options for #respond_to have to, e.g. namespace: and location:.
remove Controller::operation. this will be an option in the run/respond call. also, discourages same controller for different formats.

simplify API behavior: you have to include Representer, Representer::Deserializer now if you're expecting a string as params[:comment]. since rails does parse automatically, i decided it's easier to just let rails parse the JSON to a hash and pass the params hash into the operation.
remove Railtie. this is in trb-rails now.
we have to change public API for worker operations to satisfy sidekiq.
Resolver now allows to pass the policy object into the operation.
save @options in Operation. this simplifies ExternalModel.
rename ClassBuilder to ExternalModel, as that's exactly what is happening.
pass model from outside via options[:model] in Operation#initialize.
stronger test to make sure policy has a model.
deprecate Operation::[] in favour of Operation::().
pass params right into Operation#initialize. while this breaks the Worker because of sidekiq's API, this makes our code simpler.

Merge pull request #74 from baweaver/baweaver/typo-fixes

Minor typo fixes

introduce Op::Resolver for builders that can access model and policy:
```ruby
builds-> (model, policy, params)
```

extract Guard to policy/guard.rb.
remove BuildPolicy as this can be done via ::policy_cfg.policy.
the standard Policy is not pundit-style (without actually having to use pundit). the policies where you have a block i now call Policy::Guard.
wrap the policy evaluation into Permission.
use new uber where you can specify the context for executing ::builds blocks.

Policy::policy_class now returns the class so we can reuse it on both levels.
the #build_policy method can be used on both levels now.
rename ModelBuilder to BuildModel, what was i thinking?
params in builder is now passed properly.
introduce CRUD::ClassBuilder which builds the model on the class level and then injects it into the operation building process. this allows using the model in builders. this is experimental.
extract model building logic into ModelBuilder so we can use it on the class level, too.
new representable 2.1 needs multi_json defined explicitly.
you can now include Policy::Pundit and it will still work, without actually setting a policy.
simplify Policy::Pundit (which is actually not pundit-specific).
introduce Operation#policy which allows to evaluate arbitrary policies in your workflow.
for consistency, rename policy_block to policy_class.
make sure you don't have to define a policy block, even with Policy mixed in.
don't run tests on 1.9 anymore even though it works.
make all setup methods overridable on Trailblazer::Operation itself.
implement proper inheritance across operations for the ::policy block.
new representable 2.1 needs multi_json defined explicitly.

Merge pull request #66 from undergroundwebdesigns/master

Add autoloading support for Trailblazer::Operation::Representer
add Operation::reject that runs the block when invalid. everything else is identical to ::run.
we got Representer with inferal already.
we still don't have a stable Representer module that infers itself from the contract and includes JSON, then gets registered with the contract as deserializer.

New signature for `Operation#contract_for(model, contract_class)`. It used to be contract, then model.

this is to have consistency with #validate.

allow to use #contract before #validate. the contract will be instantiated once per #run and then memoized.
this allows to add/modify the contract _before_ you validate it using #validate.
add Operation::Module to share contracts, callbacks, methods (and parts of) between operation.
test with reform-2.0.0.rc2 and set validation backend to AM for now.
actionpack is an optional dependency now.
remove lots of README because it's on trb.org.
make it clear that we can represent formats other than json.:

remove #to_json from Responder.
we should allow using @model instead of @contract in to_json.
no need for deserializer_class. the chance that people want a separate representer and deserializer are minimal.
we can now use Form#validate with block to inject a deserializer.
parse JSON with contract and separate representer. this is so incredibly cool.
infer representers from contracts - oh my god this is so awesome!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! :firework:

introduce Disposable::Callback::Group.
remove the old #dispatch method.
pass the entire config into Endpoint.

Controller#run and friends will not change params anymore unless you say so. this used to happen for formats != :html.
You can configure that now.

class CommentsController < ..
  operation document_formats: :json

This will provide the original incoming JSON document in params["comment"] and work seamlessly with a JSON operation that uses a representer. this basically means you have to parse it yourself, so only do this when you want to use a representer in your operation (recommended) or your own parsing.
introduce Trailblazer::Endpoint to separate generic operation dispatch logic from Rails.
Check if operation is a collection using #is_a?

Set right variable name when using Controller::AR

When using Controller::ActiveRecord it tries to set the variable name
according to table name, but when we are using collection there is no
way of doing this automatically because @model is a
ActiveRecord_Relation so what is proposed is to check if @model is a
relation then set the right variable name.

This case was not supported on first collection commit because wasn't
being tested the case that a controller include AR module, now its being
covered and with tests.
fix tests as the output still uses 1.8 hashes, @askl56.

Move #model from collection and crud to operation
Small fix on collection test and run all tests on default rake task
Merge branch 'feature/add_pagination_and_scope_to_collection' of https://github.com/fernandes/trailblazer into collection
Create /tmp/uploads so worker tests can pass
allow validate(params, model, Contract) with CRUD.
Add test for AR using PostgreSQL Schemas

Merge remote-tracking branch 'hucky/master' into feature/add_support_for_tenant_models

* hucky/master:
  Handling situations where AR's table_name has been overridden with a schema and period prefix.
bump version. this is not the same as it used to be.
fix worker_test, now that we don't return params anymore.
TRY to fix autoloading by only using Rails' reloader. fixes #56 (hopefully).

API change:
1. the return value of #process is no longer returned from ::run and ::call. they always return the operation instance.
2. the return value of #validate is true or false. this allows a more intuitive operation body.

def process(params)
  if validate(params) do
    .. do valid
  else
    .. handle invalid
  end
end
don't run rake rails anymore in test. this needs to be a physically separated bundle exec rake exactly as we need it in cells, and probably all other gems.

Use more conventional route on test

Now using a collection route on test to make it follow rails routing standards

Add support for respond_with options

If you need to specify respond_with location or action for example
use in your controller:

respond_with Model, params, { location: new_location, action: :action }

`params` need to be specified because is a optional argument on respond
and I wouldn't like to change method signature, so just added responder
options
don't specify representable, just say reform > 1.2.
split loading of cells and operations.

add Operation::Dispatch to declaratively run callbacks on the instance level and declaratively skip them in subclasses on the class level. i presented that at wroc_love and other conferences without having it implemented, yet, haha. :biggrin:
Handling situations where AR's table_name has been overridden with a schema and period prefix.

Merge pull request #34 from carlosantoniodasilva/patch-1

Fix `#setup_params!` code example in README
restructure README: we start with a simple Architecture overview and walk through the concepts. then API details. this was inspired by a discussion i had at the fantastic @rubyconfby conference.

Make default rake task run all tests (test and rails)

* Create a build default task on Rakefile that runs test and rails
* Also keep the possibility to run isolated tests
* Let travis run just the default rake task

Fix `#setup_params!` code example in README

It seems it was a bad copy&paste from `#process_params!`, missing the method name change. Also improve highlight of the method name.
adding some docs. @laserlemon, do you think we can use your organizers in Trailblazer's Operation?
start working on Rollback semantics for operations.
fix autoloading, thanks to @pixeltrix and @cgaudreau for their excellent investigations. fixes #29.
Added Operation#errors as every operation maintains a contract.
updating travis ci to run rails specs
adding info about Op#process_params! to the readme.
changing test to a more proper name.
don't introduce another method but keep it in #setup_operation_instance_variables.
allowing #process_params! to be performed in an operation
run trb's autoloading AFTER the initializers to allow mixin in additional features into base classes like contracts, operations, etc.

make CRUD::included overridable by extracting it to a module, then include it on class layer. this is useful to extend the included hook, e.g. to automatically include CRUD::ActiveModel. see gemgem-trbrb for it.
add CRUD::ActiveModel that infers model name in contract automatically from Op::model.
Added `Operation#setup_model(params)` that can be overridden to add nested objects or process models right after `model!`. Don't add deserialization logic here, let Reform/Representable do that.
spec for active record module that creates instance vars for presented model

get the class -> then the table name.
following rails convernsations in terms of creating instance variables for views.

`Controller#form` did not use builders. This is fixed now.

don't use rails autoloader in crud_autoloading anymore because it is unpredictable. instead, simply require_dependency the model file explicitely, then the crud operations. this will fix your issues, @gogogarrett.

Use `request.body.string` or `read` when appropriate.

It fixes an issue:
undefined method `string' for #<Unicorn::TeeInput>
change tests to use Op.() call style.
add crud_autoloading which goes through app/concepts, finds all crud.rb files and then autoloads the model and then the actual crud file.

Rename crud autoloading file

Autoload crud files as dependecy

Trailblazer put crud operations under crud.rb files, so
this file commit add trailblazer/crud that after being required
on a rails initializer will load all CRUD stuff
fix the README, present Create doesn't make sense, thanks @zavan <3 fixes #20.
introduce Operation#present to get rid of this @validate weirdness. Both #run and #present run setup! which itself runs #model!. #model! is the new hook for providing the operation's model.
fix README, ::contract got renamed to ::present. fixes #17.

Fix behavior on when using responders on destroy operation

After #destroy AR returns the object with #destroyed? true, frozen but *true*
so responders consider as a valid object and redirect to model_path(@model.id)

correctly to models_path

more untested controller behaviour. tests coming as soon as the API is stable.
Crud::model_name becomes ::model_class to prevent name clash with AM::Naming.
Worker#deserialize returns hash with indifferent access now.

don't infer contract via Op::Contract anymore, but via Op.contract_class. Op::present is what used to be Op::contract.
TODO: sort out if we need to initialise contract_class = Form.clone. how can we warn users if they didn't setup a contractß
API change: always return the operation instance itself from a run invocation on Operation. i got confused and mostly you want the op and not the form.
allow Operation::model Song, :action as a oneliner.
add CRUD, action :update, which finds an existing model.
so much easier: the file marshal representer is now created once and uses #apply.
test that the ::run block yields the op. fixes #5.
adding support for contract-configured deserialising in Worker.
add support for builders in Operation following the best practise from cells.

Group arguments.

::run might receive multiple arguments and when ::build_operation is
called those arguments are expanded, thus causing an error because
method definition expects just one argument.

The way other arguments are passed around suggests that they should be
groped in ::build_operation definition.

Fixes failing test.
work on FileMarshaller which uses a Contract object to find out what is a file.
add Worker::FileMarshaller to automatically serialise and deserialise `file: true` properties in operations.
raise error when Operation::model wasn't called.
add Operation::CRUD to instantiate/find models for you.
add a test for an Operation without #process defined. i'm not sure if we need this built-into Trb so i leave this commented for now.

another API CHANGE: Operation.run now returns the OPERATION itself instead of the Contract instance.
added tests for using Op#validate with a block.

Merge pull request #1 from JuanitoFatas/patch-1

[ci skip] Concept tree in one code block.
[ci skip] Concept tree in one code block.
add test where we use return in validate to return arbitrary object.
remove Op:Flow as that all can be handled in Op::run.
change Op#new API: receive a hash for configuration, not positional arguments.
Operation::[] now raises an exception when the contract is invalid. this makes it _extremely_ helpful when using Operations as test factories when you fuck up the initial params.
change API Op#validate(params, model, contract), so we can make model an optional arg.
allow to THEORETICALLY pass in more than one model into Op#contract_for.
add Operation::contract which runs everything but #validate and then returns the Contract instance. this is extremely helpful for New and Edit.
allow passing multiple arguments into Op::run.
in Op#process you can now use #invalid!(result) to mark the operation as invalid.
revert making @params stateful and pass it into #process. reason: allow doing stuff like params = params[:song], which would otherwise fail due to some weirdness.
override Op#process! instead of #run, which is now the creator of the generic result array.
when calling super in Operation#run, this will create a invocation protocol-compliant result array for you. extremely handy for operations that don't need a validation.
more docs on functional operation style.
allow Operation[params] which only returns the contract. useful when using Op as factory or whenever you know the validation is valid.
added in a nutshell for readme.
Operation.run now returns the contract,not the model, per default. the model is available from the contract anyway.
somebody help me please with markdown, i'm too stupid
add first paragraph for Architecture in README.
go back and create a Tempfile in ::from_hash, apparently, the write(file.read) is not a memory issue.
for testing purposes, don't return Tempfile (and don't copy file) but return File directly.
i have to introduce a respond_to, as rails >4.0 doesn't expose UploadedFile#close :(
do NOT unlink the original UploadedFile from Rails. only close it.
UploadedFile#to_hash now cleans up so there's only a single file left and all Tempfile closed and unlinked. this includes the original Tempfile from the ActionDispatch:::UploadedFile.
in UploadedFile, don't use rename but mv to allow NFS mounts etc.
UploadedFile now accepts options: tmp_dir: "/tmp/uploads" lets you set tmp root (for distributed systems).
Operation#validate(model, params, contract=..) now infers the contract name automatically (from the local namespace).
introduce Op:Worker, which makes it ridiculously simple to background-process any Operation :) i will soon add automatic file upload serialisation.
return model, only, when block is given to ::flow.
implement Trailblazer::Flow as a module that implements the always reocurring pattern of "run this, if true, do this, else do that".
start working on a standard Operation workflow where ::flow is your main entry point and an additional block is executed when valid.
add Op:UploadedFile that helps persisting a Tempfile between upload process and processing worker.
add a comment about "complex web of objects and indirection".
add more README and a mission.
add first lines to README. happy weekend.
